verses.text: The oracle which Habakkuk the prophet saw.
verses.comment: The opening identifies this as a divine message or burden revealed to Habakkuk, similar to other prophetic books (see Isaiah 13:1). The use of 'oracle' hints at the heaviness of the prophecy.

verses.text: O LORD, how long shall I cry for help, and You do not hear? Or cry to You, 'Violence!' and You do not save?
verses.comment: Habakkuk brings his anguished prayers before God, echoing the lament of many psalmists (Ps. 13:1). This shows the biblical model of wrestling with God in prayer, expressing honest frustrations while still maintaining faith.

verses.text: Why do You make me see iniquity, and why do You look idly at wrong? Destruction and violence are before me; strife and contention arise.
verses.comment: Habakkuk questions why God allows evil and injustice. The prophet is troubled by what seems like God's indifference. This echoes the struggle of the faithful when faced with evil in the world.

verses.text: Therefore the law is powerless, and justice never goes forth. For the wicked surround the righteous; so justice goes forth perverted.
verses.comment: The collapse of justice is a major reason for Habakkuk's lament. 'The law is powerless' conveys Israel’s inability to uphold God’s covenant due to sin—a problem only ultimately remedied in the New Covenant through Christ (see Hebrews 8:8-12).

verses.text: Look among the nations, and see; wonder and be amazed. For I am doing a work in your days that you would not believe if told.
verses.comment: God's answer begins, declaring He is at work in unexpected ways. Paul quotes this verse in Acts 13:41, showing its prophetic foreshadowing of Christ’s work—a surprising, transformative act of God.

verses.text: For behold, I am raising up the Chaldeans, that fierce and impetuous nation, who march across the breadth of the earth to take dwellings not their own.
verses.comment: God reveals His instrument of judgment: the Chaldeans (Babylonians). The use of foreign nations as agents of divine justice reflects God’s sovereignty over all history. Also foreshadows the ultimate sovereignty seen in Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: They are dreaded and fearsome; their justice and dignity proceed from themselves.
verses.comment: The Babylonians are depicted as self-sufficient and proud, dispensing their own standard of justice. This stands in contrast to the humility God desires, an idea ultimately fulfilled in the humble obedience of Christ.

verses.text: Their horses are swifter than leopards, fiercer than wolves at dusk; their horsemen press proudly on. Their horsemen come from afar; they fly like an eagle swift to devour.
verses.comment: The imagery emphasizes the terrifying speed and inexorability of Babylon’s army, fulfilling prophecies like Deuteronomy 28:49. These descriptions highlight God’s justice, but also His unfathomable ways.

verses.text: They all come for violence, all their faces set forward. They gather captives like sand.
verses.comment: Their relentless violence is depicted, with captives as numerous 'as sand,' a reversal of God’s promise to Abraham (Gen. 22:17). This shows how God can use even evil nations as part of His redemptive plan.

verses.text: At kings they scoff, and at rulers they laugh. They laugh at every stronghold, for they heap up earth and capture it.
verses.comment: The Babylonians’ contempt for earthly powers highlights the futility of human defenses without God. The image of siege techniques (heaping up earth) reflects historical reality and divine providence guiding the course of nations.

verses.text: Then they sweep by like the wind and go on, guilty men whose own strength is their god.
verses.comment: Babylon’s idolatry is exposed: worship of their own power. This pride will ultimately bring about their downfall, showing how trust in temporal strength is vain compared to reliance on the living God.

verses.text: Are You not from everlasting, O LORD my God, my Holy One? We shall not die. O LORD, You have appointed them to judge; O Rock, You have established them for correction.
verses.comment: Habakkuk professes God’s eternal nature and faithfulness. He recognizes God as 'Rock' (cf. Deut. 32:4)—a foundation symbolizing stability and ultimate truth. The language hints at both God’s justice and His merciful preservation of the faithful remnant.

verses.text: You who are of purer eyes than to see evil and cannot look at wrong, why do You look on those who deal treacherously and remain silent when the wicked swallows up a man more righteous than he?
verses.comment: God’s holiness is too pure to approve evil, raising the question of why He allows greater evil to punish lesser evil. This reflects the mystery of divine providence and the call to trust God even when His ways seem inscrutable.

verses.text: You make mankind like the fish of the sea, like crawling things that have no ruler.
verses.comment: Habakkuk laments humanity’s apparent powerlessness (unlike God’s original commission—Gen. 1:28). This creates longing for a true ruler over mankind, a role ultimately fulfilled perfectly in Christ.

verses.text: The wicked bring all of them up with a hook; they drag them out with their net, and gather them in their dragnet. So they rejoice and are glad.
verses.comment: The image of the net parallels later New Testament imagery (Matt. 13:47-50), where the righteous are separated from the wicked. Here, the Babylonians rejoice in their conquests, but their apparent triumph is temporary.

verses.text: Therefore they sacrifice to their net and make offerings to their dragnet, for by them their portion is fat and their food plentiful.
verses.comment: The Babylonians idolize their own means of success, disregarding the true God. This spiritual blindness contrasts with the call to humbly receive all as a gift—anticipating Christ’s example of perfect humility and gratitude.

verses.text: Shall they then keep on emptying their net and mercilessly destroying nations forever?
verses.comment: The question challenges God’s justice, seeking hope that tyranny will not have the final word. The unresolved cry here sets up the theme of faithful waiting for divine vindication—a theme fulfilled in the coming of the Messiah and the establishment of His eternal kingdom.
